meanings.definition: To soften or break down by soaking in a liquid
meanings.sent1: I will macerate the beans in water before cooking them.
meanings.sent2: She likes to macerate fruits in juice for a refreshing snack.
meanings.sent3: The chef accidentally macerated the pasta, turning it into mush.
meanings.sent4: The rain continued to macerate the soil, making it easier to dig.
meanings.sent5: The fabric will macerate in the dye, taking on a new color.

meanings.definition: To cause to waste away or become thin
meanings.sent1: The illness began to macerate his once strong muscles.
meanings.sent2: The harsh conditions can macerate the skin if not protected.
meanings.sent3: Leaving the food out too long will macerate its freshness.
meanings.sent4: The constant stress seemed to macerate her spirit over time.
meanings.sent5: The relentless sun can macerate the paint on the old car.

meanings.definition: To become soft or disintegrate by soaking in a liquid
meanings.sent1: The paper will macerate if left in the rain.
meanings.sent2: The bread will macerate in the soup, adding flavor.
meanings.sent3: The toy accidentally fell into the water and began to macerate.
meanings.sent4: The wood started to macerate after being exposed to the humidity.
meanings.sent5: The sponge will macerate in the cleaning solution, becoming saturated.
